introduction.p: The quaternions, discovered by William Rowan Hamilton in 1843, were invented to capture the algebra of rotations of 3-dimensional real space, extending the way that the complex numbers capture the algebra of rotations of 2-dimensional real space.

Elements in the set of quaternions \Quat\Quatthe quaternions are in one-to-one correspondence with points in 4-dimensional real space \R^4. We will write r\leftrightarrow (t,x,y,z) to denote that the quaternion r corresponds to the 4-tuple (t,x,y,z) of real numbers.

subsection.title: Cartesian form and pure quaternions
subsection.p:
The quaternions i,j,k are defined as follows.
i \amp \leftrightarrow (0,1,0,0) j \amp \leftrightarrow (0,0,1,0) k \amp \leftrightarrow (0,0,0,1)
The expression r=a+bi+cj+dk is called the Cartesian formCartesian form of a quaternion of the quaternion that corresponds to the vector (a,b,c,d) in \R^4. A quaternion of the form a=a+0i+0j+0k\leftrightarrow (a,0,0,0) is called a scalarquaternionscalar quaternion quaternion or a realquaternionreal quaternion quaternion. A quaternion of the form xi+yj+zk\leftrightarrow (0,x,y,z) is called a purequaternionpure quaternion quaternion or an imaginaryquaternionimaginary quaternion quaternion. For a quaternion r=a+bi+cj+dk, we call the real quaternion a the scalar partquaternionscalar part of a quaternion or real partquaternionreal part of a quaternion of r, and we call the quaternion xi+yj+zk the vector partquaternionvector part of a quaternion or the imaginary partquaternionimaginary part of a quaternion of r. To reflect the natural correspondence of the pure quaternion xi+yj+zk with the vector (x,y,z) in \R^3, we will write \R^3_\Quat\R^3_\Quatthe space of pure quaternions
to denote the space of pure quaternions.

subsection.title: Correspondence with complex matrices
subsection.p: Analogous to the way that the complex numbers \C can be realized as the set {\mathcal M}_\C of 2\times 2 real matrices (see ), the quaternions can be realized by a set of 2\times 2 complex matrices, as follows. Let {\mathcal M}_\Quat denote the set of 2\times 2 complex matrices of the form \left[\begin{array}{cc} u \amp v\\ -v^\ast \amp u^\ast\end{array}\right]. Given a quaternion r=a+bi+cj+dk, let u,v be the complex numbers u=a+bi and v=c+di, and let {M}(r) denote the 2\times 2 matrix in {\mathcal M}_\Quat given by {M}(r)=\left[\begin{array}{cc} u \amp v\\ -v^\ast \amp u^\ast\end{array}\right]. Conversely, given a matrix M\in {\mathcal M}_\Quat, with top left entry a+bi and top right entry c+di, let Q(M) denote the quaternion r=a+bi+cj+dk. It is clear that the mappings r\to M(r) and M\to Q(M) are inverses to one another, and establish a one-to-one correspondence \Quat\leftrightarrow {\mathcal M}_\Quat.

proposition.title: {\mathcal M}_\Quat is closed under addition and multiplication

statement.p: Let M,N be elements of {\mathcal M}_\Quat. Then the sum M+N and the product MN are also elements of {\mathcal M}_\Quat.

subsection.title: Addition and multiplication
subsection.p:
By virtue of , we can define addition and multiplication of quaternions r,s as follows.
r+s=Q(M(r)+M(s)) rs=Q(M(r)M(s))
Because matrix algebra has associative and distributive laws, these carry over to quaternions. Note that quaternion multiplication is not commutative! However, for any real quaternion a, we have M(a)=a\Id, so M(a) commutes with all matrices, and therefore a commutes with all quaternions. To summarize, let q,r,s be quaternions and let a be a real quaternion. We have the following.
q(rs) \amp = (qr)s\;\; \text{ (associative law of multiplication)} q(r+s)\amp = qr+qs \;\; \text{ (distributive law)} ar\amp =ra \;\; \text{ (real quaternions commute with all quaternions)}

In practice, it is not necessary to convert quaternions to matrices in order to add and multiply. Quaternion addition and multiplication in Cartesian form is analogous to complex multiplication, using the following basic multiplication rules.
i^2=j^2=k^2=-1 ij=-ji=k, \;\; jk=-kj=i, \;\; ki=-ik=j

subsection.title: Conjugate, modulus, and polar form
subsection.p:
The conjugateconjugate of a quaternion of a quaternion r=a+bi+cj+dk is r^\ast = a-bi-cj-dk, and the modulusmodulus of a quaternion of r is |r|=\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2}. The unit quaternionsquaternionunit quaternionsgroups, list ofthe unit quaternions, denoted U(\Quat)U(\Quat)the unit quaternions, is the set of quaternions with modulus 1.The set of unit quaternions U(\Quat) is in one-to-one correspondence with the 3-sphere S^3=\{(t,x,y,z)\in \R^4\colon t^2+x^2+y^2+z^2=1\}. This is analogous to the set of norm 1 complex numbers that is in one-to-one correspondence with the 1-sphere S^1=\{(x,y)\in \R^2\colon x^2+y^2=1\}.
Analogous to complex numbers, a quaternion r can be expressed in polar formpolar form of a quaternion r=|r|(\cos \theta + u\sin \theta) where u is a pure unit quaternion and \theta is a real number.

ol.li: Show that the following construction produces a polar form for a nonzero quaternion r. Let r'=\frac{r}{|r|}=a'+b'i+c'j+d'k. If |a'|\lt 1, let u=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(a')^2}}(b'i+c'j+d'k), and let \theta=\arccos a'.
Fill in the remaining details on polar form for quaternions. What happens if r=0? What happens if |a'|=1?
Are u,\theta uniquely determined by r? If not, describe the possible choices for u,\theta.
If r=0, its polar form is simply r=0, the same as the case for complex numbers. If |a'|=1, then r'=\pm 1, so \theta=0 or \theta=\pi, and the polar form is r=\pm |r|=a.

No, u,\theta are not uniquely determined by r. If we write r(u,\theta)=|r|(\cos\theta + u\sin\theta), then we have r(u,\theta)=r(u,\theta+2\pi k)=r(-u,-\theta+2\pi k) for all k\in \Z. For the denerate case \theta=0 mod 2\pi, we have r(u,0)=r(v,2\pi k) for all k\in \Z and for all pure quaternions v. For the degenerate case r=0, we have r(u,\theta)=r(v,\phi) for all \phi\in \R and for all pure quaternions v.

subsection.title: Quaternions as rotations of \R^3_\Quat
subsection.p: Let r be a unit quaternion and let v be a pure quaternion. Let R_r(v) denote the quaternion R_r(v)=rvr^\ast. It is easy to check that (R_r(v))^\ast = -R_r(v). From this we conclude that rvr^\ast is a pure quaternion.

statement.p: Explain how we conclude that R_r(v) is pure when r is a unit quaternion and v is a pure quaternion.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Just like for complex numbers, where if z^\ast=-z, then it follows that z is pure imaginary, the analogous property holds for quaternions.

subsection.p:
It is easy to see that R_r is a linear map from the real vector space of unit quaternions to itself. That means that the following properties hold for all pure quaternions v,w and all real scalars \alpha.
R_r(v+w) \amp = R_r(v) + R_r(w) R_r(\alpha v) \amp = \alpha R_r(v)

statement.p: Show the details to prove that R_r is linear.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Using the distributive law, we have R_r(v+w)=r(v+w)r^\ast = rvr^\ast +rwr^\ast = R_r(v)+R_r(w). Using the fact that real numbers commute multiplicatively with all quaternions, we have R_r(\alpha v)= r(\alpha v)r^\ast=\alpha rvr^\ast=\alpha R_r(v).

subsection.p: We conclude with the main result of this section that shows how rotations of 3-dimensional real space are encoded in the algebra of quaternions.

statement.p: Let r=\cos\theta + u\sin\theta be a unit quaternion in polar form, and let R_r be the linear transformation of the space of pure quaternions given by v\to rvr^\ast. The action of R_r is a rotation by 2\theta radians about the axis given by the unit vector u.

Prove using the following outline. Let r=\cos\theta + u\sin\theta be a polar form for a unit quaternion r.
Show that R_r(u)=u.
Let v be any pure unit quaternion orthogonal to u, and let w=u\times v, so that the triple u,v,w forms a right-handed coordinate system for \R^3. Show that R_r(v) = \cos(2\theta)v + \sin(2\theta)w (use equation ) and then explain how this proves the Proposition.

hint.p: In deriving equation , you will obtain expressions uv-vu and uvu. Use equation to show that uv-vu=2w and uvu=v. Show that the quaternion on the right side of has norm 1. Finally, use the fact that a\cdot b = |a||b|\cos t for real vectors a,b that make an angle t at the origin to determine the angle made by v,R_r(v).

First, check that, for any pure, unit quaternion u, we have u^2=-1 (use ). Now we have
R_r(u)\amp =(\cos\theta + u\sin\theta)u(\cos\theta + u\sin\theta)^\ast \amp = (\cos\theta + u\sin\theta)(u\cos\theta + \sin\theta) \amp = u(\cos^2\theta+\sin^2\theta) - \sin\theta\cos\theta + \sin\theta\cos\theta \amp = u
as desired.

We have
R_r(v)\amp =(\cos\theta + u\sin\theta)v(\cos\theta + u\sin\theta)^\ast \amp = (\cos\theta + u\sin\theta)(v\cos\theta -vu\sin\theta) \amp = v\cos^2\theta + (uv-vu)\sin\theta\cos\theta -uvu\sin^2\theta \amp =v(\cos^2\theta -\sin^2\theta) + 2w\sin\theta\cos\theta
(to get the last expression from the next-to-last expression, use to simplify uv-vu=2u\times v=2w and uvu=v).
Using double angle formulas, the last expression in the displayed derivation becomes v\cos(2\theta) + w\sin(2\theta). Since R_r is a linear map that acts on the an orthogonal basis u,v,w as a rotation about u by the angle 2\theta, the Proposition is established.
